text: Yeah holidays were good. I'm sad it's over!! But I'm feeling motivated this year and ready to put in the work :muscle:

Of course there is no right or wrong answer about apprenticeships vs. uni, but what i would say is if you can find a decent apprenticeship (i.e. with a well-known company, and in a role that does not restrict you or pigeon-hole you), then you can definitely save a lot of money and potentially get promoted faster as uni students would have had no work experience until they graduate so you would know work-life reality and the role better.
Having if you did choose the uni route, I would strongly recommend choosing a course that had an internship or placement as part of the course.

I went to Bath University to study business administration (basically business management) and that included 2 six-month placements over the 4-year degree. I was able to earn lots of money, figure out what jobs i wanted and didnt want to do, and ultimately came out better prepared for the workplace vs other graduates

I dont think Bath accept BTECH for the business degree though, but if you were considering a business degree I would recommend getting a list of the top unis for business and going down the list starting at the very top/best uni and finding the course that DOES accept BTECH.
You might even find Cambridge/Oxford accept you! A lot of unis do something called "contextual admissions" these days which helps state school education students :smiley:

Just to give you an idea of what you might study in a Business degree, look at the "Course Structure" section of the Bath Business degree >> <https://www.bath.ac.uk/courses/undergraduate-2020/business-and-management/bsc-business-including-two-six-month-placements/#course-structure>
